title: Foreign Materials
overview: This covers citation of foreign legal materials. The Bluebook has extensive tables (T2) for specific countries. General rules: use the official source of foreign law if available, in the original language, with an English parenthetical explanation if needed. Provide jurisdiction if not obvious.
key_principles: Use the official source of foreign law if available
Provide English parenthetical explanation if needed
Always indicate jurisdiction unless obvious from context
Use table T2 for country abbreviations and specific formats

20.1.title: Jurisdiction
20.1.description: Always indicate the country (and subdivision like state or province if needed) unless it's obvious from context. Use table T2 for abbreviations.
rules: Indicate country and subdivision (state, province, canton) if needed
Use table T2 for official abbreviations
Provide English title in parenthesis if source is not in English

20.2.title: Non-English-Language Documents
20.2.description: If citing a source in a language that uses the Roman alphabet, cite in the original language, but you may provide an English translation of the title in parenthesis. If language uses a non-Roman alphabet (Chinese, Arabic, etc.), transliterate the title and then parenthesize the English translation.
key_rules: Cite in original language for Roman alphabet languages
May provide English translation of title in parenthesis
For non-Roman scripts: transliterate then translate
Include language or jurisdiction in parenthesis if needed for clarity

20.2.1.title: Documents Appearing in More than One Language
20.2.1.description: If a document is officially published in multiple languages (like some Swiss laws in German, French, Italian), cite the version you are using and can read. If an English version is official or authoritative, you can cite that. If not, cite the original.
guidance: Cite the version you are using and can read
If English version is official, you may cite that
Otherwise cite the original language
May note existence of translations if relevant

examples.example: Cite Quebec law in French even if English version exists unofficially, unless an official English is provided
Some Swiss laws are officially published in German, French, and Italian - cite the version you use

20.2.2.title: Titles and Names of Documents in Languages Other than English
20.2.2.description: Capitalize foreign titles according to the capitalization rules of that language. Italicize case names or titles of books as in English.
capitalization_rules: Follow the capitalization rules of the source language
In French: only first word and proper nouns capitalized
In German: nouns capitalized, other words lowercase unless proper nouns
In Spanish: first word and proper nouns capitalized
formatting: Italicize case names and titles as in English
Provide English translation of title in parenthesis if reader might not understand
20.2.2.example: Loi relative aux sociétés par actions [Law on Joint Stock Companies] (Belgium)

20.2.3.title: Abbreviations in Languages Other than English
20.2.3.description: Use the foreign-language abbreviations as per local convention or table T2. Do not translate abbreviations of source names.
rules: Use foreign-language abbreviations as per local convention
Consult table T2 for standardized abbreviations
Do not translate abbreviations of source names
Provide parenthetical explanation for less-known abbreviations on first use

20.2.4.title: Languages That Do Not Use the Roman Alphabet
20.2.4.description: Transliterate non-Roman scripts. Use the system given in Bluebook table (for example, pinyin for Chinese, Hepburn for Japanese, etc.). Once transliterated, treat as a foreign title (with italicization rules as appropriate).
process: Transliterate non-Roman script using appropriate system
Treat transliterated text as foreign title

20.2.5.title: Citations to Translations of Non-English-Language Documents
20.2.5.description: If you are citing a translation, indicate the translator and that it's a translation. Also, if you quote a translated passage, you might parenthetically credit the translation.
20.2.5.format: Civil Code of Germany, translated in 2 The German Civil Code: As Amended to January 1987, at 123 (Simon L. Goren trans., Fred B. Rothman & Co. 1994)
requirements: Clearly indicate it is a translation
Include publication information for the translation
For quoted passages, parenthetically credit the translation source

20.3.title: Cases
20.3.description: Cite foreign cases with the case name (if applicable, italicize as in English), the volume/reporter/page (if analogous to common law citation), and the court and date in parenthesis. Many civil law countries use case numbers and dates instead of reporter citations, so adapt accordingly.
20.3.example: Bundesverfassungsgericht [BVerfG] [Federal Constitutional Court] Mar. 3, 2004, 111 Entscheidungen des Bundesverfassungsgerichts [BVerfGE] 307 (Ger.)
guidance: Use the format provided in table T2 for each country
Adapt to specific country's citation style
Distinguish between common law and civil law formatting

20.3.1.title: Common Law Cases
20.3.1.description: Cite as: [Case Name] [year/volume] [Reporter] [page or case number] ([Court abbreviation] [Year]). For example, R. v. Smith, [2001] 2 S.C.R. 42 (Can.). If country uses year in brackets, follow their style.

structure.year_or_volume: Year in brackets [year] or volume number

guidance: Always include jurisdiction if not obvious from reporter
Include country or province as needed
Follow the year in brackets convention if used by that jurisdiction
Use official reporter names and abbreviations from table T2

20.3.2.title: Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Cases
20.3.2.description: Often no official case name; you might use the parties or a descriptor. Provide docket or decision number if available, court name, date.

structure.court_name: Name of court in original language
structure.decision_number: Docket or decision number if available
structure.reporter: Official gazette or court bulletin reference

examples.example: Conseil d'État [CE] [Council of State] June 27, 2014, Rec. Lebon 312
examples.description: French Council of State format with official publication reference

guidance: Use available references like official gazettes or court bulletins
Consult table T2 for specific country formats
Many civil law countries use case numbers and dates instead of reporter citations
Adapt citation format accordingly to jurisdiction
Always provide enough information to identify the specific case

20.4.title: Constitutions
20.4.description: Cite foreign constitutions by country name and then constitution (in English if known) and pinpoint. Provide year of adoption or amendment if relevant and not clear by context.

examples.example: Constitution of the Italian Republic art. 5

examples.note: Include year if multiple constitutions in history or if relevant

guidance: Always include country name unless obvious from context
Provide English name if known
Use original language name in italics with English translation in brackets if needed
Include year of adoption if relevant and not clear from context
Use article abbreviations consistent with source document

20.5.title: Statutes
20.5.description: Cite foreign statutes by official name (possibly translated in brackets if needed), the promulgation or code information, and date. Civil law countries often use: Law Name (date) (Country). For codes: give the article number and code name.

examples.example: Official Journal citation for official gazette

guidance: Use official name of statute/code
Provide English translation in brackets if needed
Include promulgation date or code article information
Always include country abbreviation in parentheses
Consult table T2 for jurisdiction-specific formats

20.5.1.title: Statutes in Common Law Systems
20.5.1.description: Common law jurisdictions often mirror U.S./U.K. style: Title (Jurisdiction year). Include jurisdiction abbreviation if sub-national (like Ontario or New South Wales).

examples.example: Australian Consumer Law, Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) sch 2 (Austl.)

components.title: Australian Consumer Law, Competition and Consumer Act

guidance: Use their official compilation or session law citation
Include jurisdiction abbreviation if sub-national
Follow the citation style of that common law jurisdiction
Include schedule or part references as applicable
Use table T2 for country-specific abbreviations

20.5.2.title: Statutes in Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Jurisdictions
20.5.2.description: Civil law: often use the date and title: e.g., Gesetz über die ... [Act on ...], Oct. 1, 2020, BGBL I at 123 (Ger.). Or the year/number style: e.g., Law No. 100 of 2006 (Japan).

formats.example: Gesetz über die ... [Act on ...], Oct. 1, 2020, BGBL I at 123 (Ger.)

guidance: Provide English description in brackets if title is not self-explanatory
Include publication reference like an official gazette citation
Use date and/or number as per country's format
Consult table T2 for each country's preferred format
Include whether it's a national or regional/provincial law if relevant

20.6.title: Non-English-Language and Foreign Periodicals
20.6.description: Cite foreign journals similar to U.S. journals, but use the original title abbreviation (per T13 for that language) and include an English translation of the title in parenthesis if not obvious.
20.6.example: 20 Revue Internationale de Droit Comparé 25 (1988) (Fr.) ("International Review of Comparative Law")

structure.english_translation: English translation of journal title in parenthesis

guidance: Use original title abbreviation from table T13 for that language
Include English translation of title if not obvious
Format similarly to U.S. journal citations
For article titles in foreign languages: may translate in parenthetical if helpful
Always provide enough information to locate the source

20.7.title: Short Citation Forms
20.7.description: Use id., supra, etc., for foreign sources similarly. If you've given an English hereinafter, use that. Ensure not to confuse foreign sources with domestic ones if similar names.

short_forms.usage: If immediately preceding footnote is exactly the same source
If an English hereinafter was given in initial citation

guidance: Use id. for immediately preceding identical source
Use supra for previously cited sources with note number
If given English hereinafter abbreviation, use that in subsequent cites
Include country abbreviation if needed to avoid confusion with similarly-named domestic sources
Example: BGHZ, supra note 12 (if using abbreviation for German case reporter)
cautions: Do not confuse foreign sources with domestic ones of similar names
Include country if needed for clarity
Ensure reader can easily trace back to full citation

common_law_countries.notes: Year often in brackets; use official reporter abbreviations
Include provincial abbreviation for sub-national laws
Include state/commonwealth abbreviation; use official reporters

civil_law_countries.notes: Use code abbreviations; consult table T2 for specific format
Use official gazette (BGBL); Bundesverfassungsgericht for constitutional cases

civil_law_countries.constitution_format: Constitution of the Italian Republic art. [number]
civil_law_countries.notes: Consult table T2 for statute-specific abbreviations

civil_law_countries.code_format: Código Civil art. [number] (Spain) or C.C. art. [number] (Spain)

civil_law_countries.notes: Use numbered law format; transliterate original language titles

mixed_systems.note: Civil law jurisdiction within common law Canada
mixed_systems.guidance: Follow civil law citation conventions but include Quebec/Que. abbreviation; cite French source unless official English available
Use appropriate reporter abbreviations; follow local citation conventions from table T2

table_t2_references.description: The Bluebook Table T2 provides country-specific citation formats, abbreviations, and sources. Always consult T2 for:
content: Preferred format for constitutions, statutes, and cases
Specific transliteration conventions for non-Roman alphabets

common_mistakes_to_avoid: Failing to include jurisdiction when required
Not following the original language capitalization rules
Confusing foreign sources with similarly-named domestic sources in short cites
Failing to transliterate non-Roman scripts properly
Not providing English translations when helpful for reader comprehension
Using English-language formatting for sources that require specific foreign citation conventions
Failing to consult table T2 for country-specific format requirements

official: Bluebook Table T13 (Foreign Language Periodical Abbreviations)
Constitutional and statutory documents in original language
reference: International Law Reports (I.L.R.) - for compiled cases
Country-specific legal databases and official repositories
Legal reference materials specific to jurisdiction
Official government websites for statutes and regulations

practical_tips.guidance: Always use the official source of foreign law if available, in the original language
When in doubt about clarity, include the country abbreviation - it's better to over-indicate than to confuse the reader
Provide English translations of titles in parentheses when the original title may not be understood by your reader
Once you establish a hereinafter abbreviation for a long foreign source title, use it consistently throughout your document
Before citing any foreign material, consult Table T2 to ensure you're using the correct format for that specific country
Cite sources in their original language even if translations are available, unless an official English version exists
In civil law jurisdictions without case names, clearly identify the court and decision number to allow reader to locate the case
